abstract.p: Westchester County Dist Atty Jeanine Pirro letter on June 6 article notes New York forgery law was amended in 1986 to apply to computer transactions

block.p: Your June 6 news article ''Man Charged With Forgery in E-Mail Scheme'' reported an indictment filed by my office against a California man who crashed the computer of a Westchester computer design company by using it to relay thousands of e-mail messages, resulting in financial damage to the company.

You say ''cyberlaw experts are currently debating whether or not junk e-mail can be considered forgery,'' and you quote one such expert who says ''the laws were not written to deal with this conduct.''

Your June 6 news article ''Man Charged With Forgery in E-Mail Scheme'' reported an indictment filed by my office against a California man who crashed the computer of a Westchester computer design company by using it to relay thousands of e-mail messages, resulting in financial damage to the company.

You say ''cyberlaw experts are currently debating whether or not junk e-mail can be considered forgery,'' and you quote one such expert who says ''the laws were not written to deal with this conduct.''

In fact, the New York forgery law was amended in 1986 to apply to computer transactions. New York State law defines a written instrument to include e-mail messages, and any written instrument that bears a false author's name may be a forgery.
Law enforcement must stay ahead of criminals seeking to hide behind computers to commit devious crimes.
JEANINE PIRRO District Atty., Westchester County White Plains, June 7, 2000
